title: Bottom app bar
description: A bottom app bar displays navigation and key actions at the bottom of mobile screens.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There's one type of bottom app bar in Material. This component provides access to up to four icon buttons as well as a floating action button (FAB).

contentChunks.footer: Bottom app bar with four icon buttons and a FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with bottom app bar containing four buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – App bars: bottomAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack Compose
Available
FlutterIn progress
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Bottom app bars draw attention to important screen actions and the floating action button (FAB)
  • A bottom app bar's layout and actions change based on the needs of the screen
  • The bottom app bar is easy to reach from a handheld position on a mobile device
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Elevation: No shadow
  • Layout: Container height is taller and the FAB is now contained within the app bar container

contentChunks.footer: Bottom app bar with four icon buttons and a FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with bottom app bar displaying 4 icon buttons and floating action button

contentChunks.footer: M2: Bottom app bar had an elevation of 8dp and did not contain the FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with floating action button above bottom app bar at higher elevation

contentChunks.footer: M3: Bottom app bar has new colors, a taller container, no elevation or shadow, and contains the FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with floating action button inside taller bottom app bar with color surface and no elevation

This section contains component attributes, token mappings, and default values for quick reference or building your own design files and implementations.
Bottom app bar
Specs for the components contained within the bottom app bar, like icon buttons and FABs, can be found on their respective pages.

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom app bar.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with bottom app bar containing three buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage
Bottom app bars provide access to up to four actions, including the floating action button (FAB).

contentChunks.footer: Bottom app bar with four icon buttons and a FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with bottom app bar containing four icon buttons and floating action button

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Bottom app bars should be used for:

  • Mobile devices only
  • Screens with two to five actions

Bottom app bars shouldn't be used for:

  • Apps with a navigation bar
  • Screens with one or no actions

contentChunks.footer: Use a bottom app bar to provide convenient access to actions.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of message feed with bottom app bar containing search delete archive and reply icon buttons and floating action button

contentChunks.footer: Don't use a bottom app bar on screens with one or no actions (other than a FAB).
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of message feed with bottom app bar containing search icon button and floating action button

contentChunks.htmlValue: When destructive actions such as Delete are placed within the bottom app bar, the interaction should trigger a snackbar to confirm the action and provide access to Undo.

contentChunks.footer: Use a snackbar to provide access to undo for destructive actions initiated from the bottom app bar.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Bottom app bars aren’t navigation bars

Navigation bars provide access to destinations in an app, whereas bottom app bars can contain both destinations and actions.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom navigation bar with four destinations.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of news feed with bottom app bar containing four navigation icons with labels

contentChunks.htmlValue: Not all products should use a bottom app bar. If the product needs more icon buttons, destinations, or a different structure, consider using alternate components or a custom layout rather than forcing actions into the bottom bar.

contentChunks.footer: Consider using a custom layout or other component if a bottom app bar doesn’t fulfill your screen’s needs, such as this set of filled buttons in a Calendar event invite.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of calendar event invite with bottom app bar containing three filled buttons to RSVP

contentChunks.footer: Don’t force actions into a bottom app bar. The icons in this Calendar event invite don’t clearly communicate their meaning.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of calendar event invite with bottom app bar containing four icon buttons and floating action button

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. FAB (optional)
3. Icon button
4. Icon button for overflow menu
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of bottom app bar indicating the 4 parts of its anatomy

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

Bottom app bar containers hold all bottom app bar elements.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom app bar container.
contentChunks.altText: Bottom app bar container

contentChunks.htmlValue:
FAB (optional)

When present, a floating action button (FAB) is displayed within the bottom app bar. In this case, the FAB has zero elevation and no shadow because the app bar container separates it from other screen content.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom app bar containing a FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of message feed with bottom app bar containing floating action button

contentChunks.footer: Do not place a FAB outside of a bottom app bar, as it makes it harder to reach.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of message feed with floating action button above bottom app bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icon buttons

The bottom app bar can hold four icon buttons on the left side of the screen, including an overflow menu icon button (three dots).

contentChunks.footer: Bottom app bar with an overflow menu.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of photos app with bottom app bar containing overflow edit audio and image button icons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement

With a top app bar

When used with a bottom app bar, top app bars can provide navigation and additional actions. Throughout an app, actions should be organized and divided consistently across both bars.

The following items benefit from specific placement:

  • Place navigation control in a top app bar
  • Place a single overflow menu control as the trailing action
  • Place actions, like Search, in a consistent location throughout the app

contentChunks.footer: Use a top app bar as a container for upwards navigation on secondary screens.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with top app bar on secondary screen

contentChunks.footer: Place an overflow menu as the last action between the app bars.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile screen with a top app bar containing an overflow menu

contentChunks.footer: A bottom app bar can provide consistent access to actions, such as navigation and search, allowing the top app bar to hold contextual, screen-specific actions.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with bottom app bar containing an overflow menu

contentChunks.htmlValue:
With snackbars

To avoid obstruction, snackbars should animate in place vertically above a bottom app bar. Refer to snackbars for more guidance on its layout and positioning.

contentChunks.footer: Inset a snackbar or toast above a bottom app bar and FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of photos app with snackbar above bottom app bar

contentChunks.footer: Don't place a snackbar in front of a bottom app bar or FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of photos app with snackbar inside bottom app bar with increased height below icon buttons and floating action button

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout

To support the intent of different sections of an app, the layout and actions of a bottom app bar can be changed to suit each screen.

For example, screens can display more or fewer actions according to what suits the screen content best.

contentChunks.footer: To showcase a primary action, this bottom app bar uses a right-aligned FAB.
contentChunks.altText: UI with bottom app bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Large screen

Bottom app bars are not recommended for use on large screens. When designing a large-screen view of a mobile product with a bottom app bar, adjust to an alternate composition.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use a bottom app bar on a desktop or large screen.
contentChunks.altText: Large screen UI with bottom app bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Density

Always use the minimum height for bottom app bars.

contentChunks.footer: Inset a snackbar or toast above a bottom app bar and FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of photos app with snackbar above bottom app bar

contentChunks.footer: Don’t apply density to app bars.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with a comact density

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Alignment

Align the layout of elements to the edges of the container. This means the primary action, such as the FAB, is on the right, and secondary actions, such as icon buttons, are on the left.

This arrangement reinforces the hierarchy of actions. It remains the same no matter the reading direction of the screen’s language.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom app bar alignment is the same whether the text is a right-to-left (RTL) or left-to-right (LTR) language.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of message feet

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Scrolling

Upon scroll, the bottom app bar can appear or disappear:

  • Scrolling downward hides the bottom app bar. If a FAB is present, it detaches from the bar and remains on screen.
  • Scrolling upward reveals the bottom app bar, and reattaches to a FAB if one is present.

contentChunks.footer: A FAB can remain on screen, even as a bottom app bar hides when scrolled off-screen.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of message feed with bottom app bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Transitions

When the primary bottom app bar transitions into a secondary bottom app bar, several things occur:

  • The FAB’s primary icon fades out, while the secondary icon fades in
  • The bottom app bar’s primary icons fade out, and secondary icons fade in (on the bar’s left-hand side)

When the secondary bottom app bar transitions into a primary bottom app bar, several things occur:

  • The FAB’s secondary icon fades out, while the primary icon fades in
  • The bottom app bar’s secondary icons fade out, and primary icons fade in (on the bar’s left-hand side)

contentChunks.footer: A FAB can remain on screen, even as a bottom app bar hides when scrolled off-screen.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of message feed with primary bottom app bar transitioning to secondary

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Opening menus

Menus that are generated by the bottom app bar (such as an overflow menu) open as a menu at a higher elevation than the bar.

contentChunks.footer: This menu opens from a bottom app bar.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of photos app with elevated open menu positioned above bottom app bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Elements that cover the bottom app bar

The bottom app bar can be covered by keyboards and other temporary surfaces. If your app requires frequent obstruction of the bar, another component should be used instead.

contentChunks.footer: A keyboard can temporarily cover a bottom app bar.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with exposed keyboard obscuring bottom app bar

contentChunks.footer: Don't attach a bottom app bar to the top of the keyboard.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI with exposed keyboard attached below repositioned bottom app bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
